comments.author: DaveF
comments.body: Quote from: zasad@ on November 09, 2022, 02:18:30 PMUnder this standard, almost every cryptocurrency, including Ethereum and Doge, are securities. I can see putting Ethereum in there, pre-sale, promises, and a ton of other things. Doge was started as a joke and never made any promises other then 'much coin'But, and this is just me saying this just an opinion, they did a lot of things in terms of marketing, promotion and what not that made them a target.There are a lot of other projects out there that are still around and not being bothered. I don't want to say just another shitcoin scam, but this one got the eyes of the government on it. But, I can't think of any other way to put it.Just my opinion.-Dave

comments.author: zasad@
comments.body: https://cointelegraph.com/news/sec-settles-on-security-claim-in-lbry-case-community-calls-it-a-big-win-for-cryptoSEC settles on security claim in LBRY case; community calls it a big win for crypto"The SEC was hoping to seek affirmation on an ambiguous injunction after scoring a victory during a hearing in November 2022, but judges made it clear that the judgment was only for the direct sale.The United States Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) admitted on record that the sale of LBRY Credits (LBC) tokens in the secondary market doesn’t constitute a security. The settlement came during an appeal hearing in the LBRY vs. SEC case on Jan. 30."

comments.author: pawel7777
comments.body: Quote from: DaveF on November 11, 2022, 12:58:10 PMI can see putting Ethereum in there, pre-sale, promises, and a ton of other things.That's not quite true. I understand we're on bitcoin forum and any form of sh***ting on ETH is encouraged, but in reality, it was made clear that the so-called 'pre-sale' was not an investment (you had to accept a disclaimer in big, bold, red letters saying so), that you were not buying anything, that there was no guarantee that the devs will actually develop anything and that any funds raised were donations to the project and any participants were to be rewarded in ETH tokens, proportionally to their donation, should the project be successful.Objectively speaking, they've done pretty solid work there.Quote from: MarathonA on November 13, 2022, 06:38:33 AMMany projects will simply avoid the USA.This.

comments.author: zasad@
comments.body: The ethereum and ICO team received bitcoins, and bitcoin is a commodity. If you look at the judicial practice, the SEC punishes such projects with a fine in the amount of the amount received for the ICO and penalties. For ethereum, this is a very small fine and the company will pay it, for other projects this fine will be the reason for closing the project.

I thought they'd calculate the assets of the company they punish so if they refused to pay they can just seize them. It is hard to believe they just take the raised ICO numbers as punishment as you mentioned above without considering anything else.These events happen frequently because many tokens are securities under US law. Some companies are less affected by fines because they prevented US residents from buying tokens, or used licensed intermediaries who monitored it.Another question is what investors bought for: fiat or cryptocurrencies.One of the punishment options is the amount of sale of tokens (shares) on ICO plus interest and penalties. For most companies, this is bankruptcy.
